title: 108_s1330
content: The Act may be cited as the "Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area Act". The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm transportation corridor in Alaska is a significant gateway with a rich history of indigenous people and pioneers. The region's natural beauty includes evidence of earthquakes, avalanches, glaciers, and tidal action. The cultural landscape reflects human fortitude and resourcefulness in the face of rugged terrain and harsh conditions. The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm region in Alaska holds a national interest in recognizing, preserving, and interpreting its historic routes and natural beauty. This includes elements like the Iditarod National Historic Trail, the Seward Highway National Scenic Byway, and the Alaska Railroad National Scenic Railroad. National heritage area designation allows for the interpretation of these routes and the region's significance. The national heritage area designation supports the interpretation of historic routes in the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm region, fostering regional coordination and partnerships among communities and various historical associations. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, and interpret the historic and modern resources of the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm historic transportation corridor. Various organizations and associations are involved in this effort, including the Alaska Historical Commission, the Kenai Peninsula Borough, and the Anchorage Municipal Assembly. The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm historic transportation corridor aims to preserve resources and promote public enjoyment. It also seeks to foster cooperative planning among communities and government entities through financial and technical assistance. The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area, established by this Act, defines key terms such as "Heritage Area," "management entity," "management plan," and "Secretary." The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area is established with defined boundaries in the Kenai Mountains and upper Turnagain Arm region. A management entity will oversee the area. The Secretary will enter into a cooperative agreement with the management entity for the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area, outlining goals, conservation approaches, and protection measures. The management entity is not authorized to assume management responsibilities on Federal lands. Other organizations are encouraged to participate in the development and implementation of the management plan. The management plan for the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area involves various organizations including the State Division of Parks, the Forest Service, and the National Park Service. Ex-officio members will be represented in the non-profit corporation according to the bylaws of the management entity. The management entity for the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area has authorities and duties outlined in Section 6. The management entity for the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area must develop a management plan within 3 years of the cooperative agreement. The plan should include recommendations for conservation, funding, and development, agreements on actions by Government and private organizations, and sources of funding for the Heritage Area. The management entity for the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area must develop a management plan within 3 years of the cooperative agreement. The plan should include recommendations for conservation, funding, and development, agreements on actions by Government and private organizations, and sources of funding for the Heritage Area. Additionally, the management entity should prioritize implementing actions, goals, and policies from the cooperative agreement and heritage plan, including assisting communities with recognizing resource values, promoting economic viability, and maintaining interpretive exhibits in the Heritage Area. The management entity for the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area is responsible for developing and implementing a management plan that includes improving interpretive exhibits, heritage trails, public awareness, restoring historic buildings, and ensuring clear signage. Additionally, they must conduct at least 2 public meetings each year to discuss the plan's initiation and implementation. The management entity for the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area must conduct at least 2 public meetings each year to discuss the implementation of the management plan. They shall place a notice of each meeting in a newspaper and make the meeting minutes available to the public. The Secretary, in consultation with the Governor of Alaska, may enter into a cooperative agreement with the management entity for the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area. The agreement must involve public participation and may include various forms of assistance to support the purposes of the Act. SEC. 8. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. This Act does not grant zoning powers to the management entity. It does not affect the authority of governments to regulate land use. It also does not restrict business activities. SEC. 9. PROHIBITION ON ACQUISITION OF REAL PROPERTY. The management entity cannot use funds to acquire real property. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: $350,000 authorized for the first year, $1,000,000 for subsequent years, with a total cap of $10,000,000 for the Heritage Area. Federal funding must be matched by 25% from other sources. The Secretary cannot provide assistance beyond 15 years from the completion of a cooperative agreement.
